clients.title: Mrs

family_members.name: Michael
family_members.notes: Associate Architect at Sterling Architects Ltd, £72k salary, mild hypertension controlled with medication

family_members.name: Emily
family_members.notes: Age 14, St Catherine's School Weybridge, academically gifted, predicted A*/A grades, wants to study medicine or veterinary science

family_members.name: Oliver
family_members.notes: Age 11, St Catherine's School, more creative like Michael, interested in art and design

life_events.description: Emily starting GCSEs - potential tutoring costs
Emily starting university - estimated £40k funding needed
Mortgage fixed rate expires - needs review before March 2026
Family holiday to Australia planned - budget £15,000, visiting Sarah's emigrated best friend

concerns.details: Sarah feels 'behind' on pension savings compared to colleagues. Concerned whether they're saving enough for retirement. Target retirement: Sarah 60, Michael 62 with £50-60k combined income.
Surprised by estimated £160k IHT liability. Both from middle-class backgrounds, not used to estate planning. Don't want to burden children with IHT bill.
Very focused on Emily and Oliver's education. Private school fees £2,600/month. University costs estimated £40k per child. Emily academically gifted, may study medicine (5-6 years).
Michael has no critical illness cover and no income protection beyond statutory sick pay. Father died at 68 of heart attack. Michael has hypertension. May face underwriting issues.
Current fixed rate expires March 2026. Outstanding £287k @ 3.89%. Need to review options before expiry.

policies.notes: Defined Benefit - Final Salary. Accrual 1/60th. 8 years service. Projected £28k/year at 65. 50% spouse pension. DO NOT TRANSFER - extremely valuable.
Previous employer WPP Group 2008-2016. Vanguard LifeStrategy 60%. Charges 0.41%.
LifeStrategy 80% Equity. Sarah manages own investments, reads FT and Monevator.
Level Term Assurance. 20 year term expires 2038. Includes £150k Critical Illness. In trust for Michael and children.

risk_profile.notes: Sarah: 7/10 Adventurous/Growth. Managed own ISAs 10+ years. Read Tim Hale's Smarter Investing. Comfortable with volatility. Michael: 6/10 Balanced/Growth, slightly more cautious.

meeting_notes.summary: Initial comprehensive fact-find meeting at client's home. Both well-prepared with documentation. Sarah took lead but Michael fully engaged. Triggered to act after friends recommended firm. Recent 40th+ birthdays focused minds on retirement.
meeting_notes.transcript:
Key discussion points:

RETIREMENT: Sarah ideally retire 58-60, feeling 'burned out' at times from intense Unilever pace. Michael more flexible, enjoys work but wants reduced hours from 60. Want to travel (Australia, NZ, Japan), spend time with future grandchildren. Concerned £50k/year may not be enough - will model £60k scenarios.

PROPERTY: Love Weybridge home, no plans to move unless downsizing in retirement. House valued £875k (paid £495k in 2012). Mentioned possible retirement to Winchester (near Sarah's sister Emma) or Devon/Cornwall.

PROTECTION: Both understand importance given mortgage and children. Sarah has excellent employer benefits. Critical gap: Michael has NO critical illness cover and NO income protection. Michael's father died age 68 (heart attack). Michael has hypertension - seemed uncomfortable discussing, Sarah had to encourage sharing. URGENT recommendation for CI cover but expect underwriting issues.

WILLS/LPA: Current wills from 2019, need update. No LPAs in place - significant gap.

INVESTMENTS: Sarah knowledgeable, follows Monevator, read Tim Hale. Comfortable with passive approach. 80/20 equity/bond split appropriate. Michael less engaged but trusts Sarah. His workplace pension in default fund never reviewed - opportunity. Both interested in ESG but not strict ethical.

CHILDREN: Emily (14) very academic, predicted straight As, wants medicine/vet. Oliver (11) more creative like Michael. School fees £2,600/month committed until sixth form. JISAs: Emily £18.4k, Oliver £14.2k.
key_points: Sarah feeling burned out at Unilever, wants to retire by 60
Michael's father died age 68 of heart attack - family history concern
Michael has NO critical illness cover or income protection - URGENT
Wills from 2019 need update, NO LPAs in place
Emily predicted A*/A grades, wants to study medicine
Mortgage fixed rate expires March 2026 - needs review
action_items: Get CI quotes for Michael (expect underwriting loadings)

follow_ups.commitment: Prepare comprehensive suitability report covering retirement, pension consolidation, protection, university funding, tax and estate planning
Get critical illness quotes for Michael with full medical underwriting
Schedule follow-up meeting to present recommendations

interactions.summary: Initial fact-find meeting at client's home, Weybridge. 2h15m comprehensive review.
interactions.next_action: Prepare suitability report for 6th December meeting

interactions.summary: Sarah called to confirm meeting and ask what documents to prepare
testing

compliance.notes: New client as of November 2024. First annual review due November 2025.

clients.notes: Excellent client engagement. Sarah financially literate, Michael fully engaged. Strong financial position but gaps to address. Retirement goals achievable with right planning. Good long-term planning client.

clients.title: Mr

family_members.name: Sarah
family_members.notes: Arts Council Senior Manager, 4 days/week, £72k salary. Considering 3 days/week from 2026 (-£18k income). Had hypertension, now controlled at 125/78.

family_members.name: Oliver
family_members.notes: Age 16, Westminster School, applying to Oxbridge/Durham/Bristol for Economics. University September 2025.

family_members.name: Sophie
family_members.notes: Age 13, Westminster School. University 2029.

life_events.description: David bonus £60k expected - recommend £20k VCT + £20k ISA + £20k pension carry-forward = £18k tax saved
French property viewing trip to Luberon, Provence. £400k budget.
Oliver starting university - if Oxbridge, costs £45k (vs £40k planned). JISA £28.4k with £12k/year supplement.
Remortgage decision required - current fix expires May 2026. £285k @ 2.89%. If French property: increase to £585k.

concerns.details: David working 70+ hours/week. Considering exit to consulting (£120k vs £245k current). Physical and mental fatigue at age 49.
David: £220k adjusted income, lost all PA, paying 45% over £125k. Major inefficiency. VCT investment recommended for 30% relief.
concerns.notes: Increased pension to 15% (saves £12,450 tax). VCT £30k/year pending.

concerns.details: £1M+ in equities, approaching retirement (9 years). Currently 75/25 allocation. Should de-risk to 60/40 at age 55.
Planning £400k property in Provence. Currency risk (£/€), rental voids if not used, maintenance £10k/year. Residency implications if permanent move.
Sarah CI cover £150k recommendation postponed - had hypertension (now controlled BP 125/78). Re-quote January 2025.
concerns.notes: BP now controlled. Re-quoting in progress.

policies.notes: Increased contribution 8%→15% (Oct 2025). Saves £12,450 tax. Consolidated Barclays pension (£145k) Dec 2024, saves £1,200/year fees.
Sarah's Defined Benefit - accrued £22k/year. Considering 3 days/week from 2026 would reduce accrual.
Sarah's SIPP from previous role.
Includes £200k Critical Illness. In trust. Expires 2035.

risk_profile.notes: David very analytical (banking background), likes detailed projections. Currently 75/25 equity/bond. Should de-risk to 60/40 at 55. Both wine enthusiasts.

meeting_notes.summary: October 2025 review follow-up. David bonus £85k (above average). Sarah promoted to £72k. Oliver applying universities. Reviewed remortgage options and French property strategy.
key_points: David bonus £85k - allocated £40k to mortgage, £45k to ISAs
Oliver applying Oxbridge, Durham, Bristol for Economics

follow_ups.commitment: Re-quote Sarah CI cover £150k - BP now controlled at 125/78
David VCT research and options presentation
Remortgage options presentation and decision
follow_ups.notes: Current fix expires May 2026. Options: 5yr (4.1%) or 10yr (4.4%). If French property, increase to £585k.

interactions.summary: David email - bonus £60k confirmed for March
Review meeting - bonus allocation, French property, remortgage options
Sarah call - CI re-quote discussion. BP now controlled.

value_delivered: Pension contribution optimization 8%→15% - saves £12,450 tax annually
Wills updated November 2024 - mirror wills, children at 25

clients.notes: David very analytical (banking background), likes detailed projections. Sarah more lifestyle/family focused. Both wine enthusiasts. Chinese heritage - annual HK trips to see David's parents. Children academically gifted.

clients.title: Mr

family_members.name: Sybil
family_members.notes: Age 65, co-owner Fawlty Towers. Pragmatic, fatigued, focused on quality of life. Increasingly keen to exit hotel regardless of price.

life_events.description: Target hotel exit during 2026-27 window. Sale preferred but lease option available.
CGT Business Asset Disposal Relief deadline - strong incentive to complete sale before any legislative changes. Estimated gain £925k, BADR at 10% = £92,500 tax.
Continued Spain winter rentals - purchase target £120k if hotel sold. Residency/healthcare implications need addressing.

concerns.details: Hotel remains unsold after 2024-25 listing at £1.45M. Market feedback: £1.2-1.3M realistic. Basil resistant to price reduction despite market evidence. Illiquidity and over-pricing delaying exit.
concerns.notes: Basil ego-attached to hotel as life's work. Sybil pragmatic, fatigued.

concerns.details: Business Asset Disposal Relief at 10% could save £92,500 on £925k estimated gain. If sale delayed and legislation changes, tax liability materially increases. URGENT - key lever to unlock Basil's decision.
Both aged 67/65, running 12-room hotel is physically demanding. Winter closures (Dec-Feb) reinforce desire to retire. Health impacts of prolonged stress.
Current wills from 1995 - 30 years out of date. No LPAs in place. Cross-border estate considerations if Spain residency pursued.

policies.notes: Basil's SIPP. No current contributions.
Sybil's personal pension.
Joint ISAs. Not currently contributing due to business cashflow needs.

risk_profile.notes: Post-retirement, income drawdown flexibility needed. Target £65k/year retirement income.

meeting_notes.summary: January 2026 review. Hotel still unsold. Market consensus £1.2-1.3M. Basil still believes £1.45M achievable despite evidence. Sybil increasingly frustrated. Discussed lease option as interim bridge.
key_points: Sybil renewed frustration over delayed sale
BADR eligibility critical - 10% vs higher rate
action_items: Confirm BADR eligibility and legislative status
Revisit sale price with updated market evidence
Spain residency and tax planning clarification

follow_ups.commitment: Confirm BADR eligibility and check for legislative changes
Prepare updated wills recommendation - current from 1995
LPA recommendation and process
Spain residency tax implications research

interactions.summary: January review - hotel sale strategy, BADR, wills/LPAs
Agent update - pricing guidance unchanged at £1.2-1.3M
Sybil call - renewed frustration over delayed sale. Wants to exit regardless of price.

clients.notes: Basil highly ego-attached to hotel as life's work. Sybil pragmatic, fatigued, focused on quality of life. No children reduces need to retain UK base. Basil responds best to authoritative data and tax clarity. BADR framing likely key lever to unlock decision.

clients.title: Mrs

family_members.name: Richard (deceased)
family_members.notes: Passed away October 2025 after long illness. Was a chartered accountant. Anne now managing finances alone for first time.

family_members.name: Catherine
family_members.notes: Age 39, lives in Bristol with husband and 2 children. Close relationship with Anne.

family_members.name: William
family_members.notes: Age 36, lives in Edinburgh. Works in finance.

family_members.name: Emily
family_members.notes: Catherine's daughter, age 6

family_members.name: Thomas
family_members.notes: Catherine's son, age 3

life_events.description: Richard passed away after long illness. Anne now managing finances alone for first time in 45 years of marriage.
Anne's 70th birthday - first significant birthday without Richard
Granddaughter Emily's 8th birthday

concerns.details: Richard always handled investments and financial decisions during 45-year marriage. Anne has never managed money alone. Feeling overwhelmed and anxious about making wrong decisions.
concerns.notes: Needs patient, clear explanations. Don't rush decisions.

concerns.details: Wants to ensure grandchildren (Emily 6, Thomas 3) benefit from estate. Considering gifts now vs waiting. Worried about IHT.
Concerned whether inherited investments plus pensions will last. Doesn't want to burden children. Very frugal mindset.
Large family home now feels empty. Mentioned staying for memories but house is expensive to run. Children encouraging downsizing but emotionally difficult.
concerns.notes: Non-financial but affects decision-making. Be sensitive.

policies.notes: Defined Benefit. £18,000/year index-linked. Widow's portion of Richard's pension adds £8,000/year.
Inherited from Richard. Needs review - currently in cash after transfer. Income drawdown to set up.
Inherited from Richard. Conservative allocation needed for Anne's risk profile.

risk_profile.notes: Very cautious. Richard handled all investments. Needs simple explanations and reassurance. Don't recommend complex products.

meeting_notes.summary: First meeting since Richard's passing. Anne emotional but coping. Overwhelmed by financial decisions. Inherited SIPP sitting in cash. Teachers pension plus widow's portion provides solid base. Main concern is making wrong decisions without Richard.
key_points: Richard passed October 2025 after long illness
Anne never managed finances in 45-year marriage
Inherited SIPP £340k sitting in cash - needs investment
Large house expensive to run but emotionally attached
action_items: Simple investment proposal for inherited SIPP
Gentle discussion about downsizing options (not rushing)

follow_ups.commitment: Prepare simple investment proposal for inherited SIPP - low risk, income focus
follow_ups.notes: Keep it simple - she's overwhelmed. Maximum 3 fund options.

follow_ups.commitment: Create income sustainability projection to reassure about long-term security
Phone call to check in - how is she coping?
follow_ups.notes: Welfare check, not business. Be human.

interactions.summary: First meeting post-bereavement. Home visit to Anne. Emotional but coping. Discussed inherited SIPP, income needs, grandchildren.
Catherine (daughter) called on behalf of Anne to notify of Richard's passing and ask for help with finances.

compliance.notes: Bereaved client - handle with extra care. Don't rush decisions.

clients.notes: Recently widowed after 45-year marriage. Never managed money alone. Needs patient, clear explanations. Don't recommend complex products. Check in regularly - welfare as important as financial advice. Catherine (daughter) helpful point of contact if needed.
